title: Getting started with DAEDALUS
text: model can run country territory included package data simply passing name daedalus(). country_names vector holds list country territory names data available. Passing country name directly leads model accessing country characteristics stored package data. modify country characteristics, example examine assumptions around changed contact patterns, users instead create object class <daedalus_country>, allows setting certain country characteristics custom values. class also allows users collect country data one place easily. package provides data Walker et al. (2020) country demography, country workforce per economic sector, social contacts age groups country_data. package also provides data Jarvis et al. (2024) workplace contacts economic sectors. datasets accessed internal functions reduce need user input.
code: # get default values for Canada (chosen for its short name) daedalus_country("Canada") #> <daedalus_country> #> • Name: Canada #> • Demography: 1993132, 5949109, 22966942, and 6832974 #> • Community contact matrix: #>             0-4      5-19    20-64       65+ #> 0-4   1.9157895 1.5235823 5.014414 0.3169637 #> 5-19  0.5104463 8.7459756 6.322175 0.7948344 #> 20-64 0.4351641 1.6376280 7.821398 1.0350292 #> 65+   0.1187166 0.7488765 3.639207 1.5142917 #> • GNI (PPP $): 46050 #> • Hospital capacity: 7989  # make a <daedalus_country> representing Canada # and modify contact patterns country_canada <- daedalus_country(   "Canada",   parameters = list(     contact_matrix = matrix(5, 4, 4) # uniform contacts across age groups   ) )  # print to examine; only some essential information is shown country_canada #> <daedalus_country> #> • Name: Canada #> • Demography: 1993132, 5949109, 22966942, and 6832974 #> • Community contact matrix: #>      [,1] [,2] [,3] [,4] #> [1,]    5    5    5    5 #> [2,]    5    5    5    5 #> [3,]    5    5    5    5 #> [4,]    5    5    5    5 #> • GNI (PPP $): 46050 #> • Hospital capacity: 7989

title: Getting started with DAEDALUS
text: daedalus allows users quickly model one seven historical epidemics accessing infection parameters associated epidemics, stored package data. Epidemics associated infection parameters given package dependency daedalus.data daedalus.data::epidemic_names. Users can pass epidemic names directly daedalus() use default infection parameters. modify infection parameters associated epidemic, users create <daedalus_infection> class Users can also override epidemic-specific infection parameter values creating <infection> class object. infection() class helper function details parameters included.
code: daedalus.data::epidemic_names #> [1] "sars_cov_1"           "influenza_2009"       "influenza_1957"       #> [4] "influenza_1918"       "sars_cov_2_pre_alpha" "sars_cov_2_omicron"   #> [7] "sars_cov_2_delta" # not run output <- daedalus("Canada", "influenza_1918") # SARS-1 (2004) but with an R0 of 2.3 daedalus_infection("sars_cov_1", r0 = 2.3) #> <daedalus_infection> #> • Epidemic name: sars_cov_1 #> • R0: 2.3 #> • sigma: 0.217 #> • p_sigma: 0.867 #> • epsilon: 0.58 #> • rho: 0.003 #> • eta: 0.018, 0.082, 0.018, and 0.246 #> • hfr: 0.255, 0.255, 0.255, and 0.255 #> • gamma_Ia: 0.476 #> • gamma_Is: 0.25 #> • gamma_H_recovery: 0.044 #> • gamma_H_death: 0.05  # Influenza 1918 but with mortality rising with age daedalus_infection("influenza_1918", hfr = c(0.01, 0.02, 0.03, 0.1)) #> <daedalus_infection> #> • Epidemic name: influenza_1918 #> • R0: 2.5 #> • sigma: 0.909 #> • p_sigma: 0.669 #> • epsilon: 0.58 #> • rho: 0.003 #> • eta: 0.073, 0.064, 0.02, and 0.152 #> • hfr: 0.01, 0.02, 0.03, and 0.1 #> • gamma_Ia: 0.4 #> • gamma_Is: 0.4 #> • gamma_H_recovery: 0.2 #> • gamma_H_death: 0.2

what: Representing vaccine investment for pandemic preparedness
title: Getting started with DAEDALUS
text: daedalus includes vaccination response model. default response assumes advance, pre-pandemic investment vaccine specific pandemic-causing pathogen. scenario (vaccine_investment = "none") intended represent Covid-19 pandemic, assumes vaccine becomes available 1 year pandemic begins, slow roll , uptake low. parameters contained package data daedalus::vaccine_scenario_data, total four scenarios advance vaccine investment (“none”, “low”, “medium”, “high”). Vaccine investment scenarios can passed string daedalus() use default parameters scenario, <daedalus_vaccination> object using daedalus_vaccination(name, country) modify vaccination parameters. Note country information needed calculate numerical uptake limit scenario.
code: # the default vaccine investment scenario for the UK daedalus_vaccination("none", "GBR") #> <daedalus_vaccination/daedalus_response> #> Vaccine investment scenario: none #> • Start time (days): 365 #> • Rate (% per day): 0.143 #> • Uptake limit (%): 40 #> • Efficacy (%): 50 #> • Waning period (mean, days): 180

title: Getting started with DAEDALUS
text: Run model passing country infection arguments daedalus(). vaccine investment scenarios automatically assumed “none”. model runs 300 timesteps default; timesteps interpreted days since model parameters terms days. Plot data view epidemic curve.
code: # simulate a Covid-19 wild type outbreak in Canada; using default parameters data <- daedalus("Canada", "sars_cov_2_pre_alpha") data <- get_data(data) ggplot(   data[data$compartment == "infect_symp" & data$age_group == "20-64", ] ) +   geom_line(     aes(time, value, colour = econ_sector),     show.legend = FALSE   ) +   facet_wrap(     facets = vars(age_group)   )

title: Value of educational time lost
text: value school year country (\(\text{VSY}_c\)) product country-specific gross national income (\(\text{GNI}_c\)) per capita, rate return education (\(R\)), present value expected future earnings (denote \(V\)). \[\text{VSY}_c = \text{GNI}_c \times V \times R\]

title: Value of educational time lost
text: following constants assumed calculating value school year: \(r = 0.03\): discount rate future earnings; \(m_Y = 45\): expected future years work; \(= 12.5\): mean age school-going individuals. Note mean age school-goers simple mean age-bin [5, 20). \(R = 0.08\): rate return one year education.

title: Value of educational time lost
text: value lost education product : number school days lost due pandemic-mitigation measures (DAEDALUS, school closures); explained ; \(1 - E_{\text{remote}}\): loss educational efficacy due remote education closures; \(\text{VSD}_c\): value school day, value school year divided 365 (\(\text{VSY}_c / 365\)); \(N\): number school age children. \[\text{VSD}_c \times N \times (1 - O_{\text{edu}}) \times T \times (1 - E_{\text{remote}})\] number school days lost calculated product closure coefficient educational sector (\(1 - O_{\text{edu}}\)) number days pandemic-mitigation measure active \(T\). closure coefficient indicates stringency measures applied schooling, can take value range \([0, 1]\).

what: Life expectancy and years of life lost
title: Value of life-years lost
text: Life-expectancy data terms years country territory initially accessed age-bins separated sex, Global Burden Disease Collaborative Network (2020). life-expectancy data aggregated DAEDALUS age bins: 0 – 4, 5 – 19 (school age), 20 – 65 (working age), 65+ (retired working). Note aggregation simple mean across age-bins raw data; appropriate approach aim add future weighted mean takes account size age-bin raw data. results four life-expectancy values country, corresponding one four DAEDALUS age groups.

title: Value of life-years lost
text: Many policies aim improve longevity, decreasing risk death year. value risk reductions often expressed value per statistical life (VSL); times value per statistical life year (VSLY) may used. VSL concept widely misunderstood. value analyst, government, individual places saving identified life certainty. Instead, reflects individuals’ willingness exchange money small change risk, 1 10,000 decrease chance dying specific year (Robinson et al. 2019). value statistical life individual country \(c\) age group \(\) denoted \(\text{VSL}_{c_i}\) product country-specific VLY (\(\text{VLY}_{c}\)) country- age-specific life expectancy (\(T_{c_i}\)), depends country age-group individual; can expressed : \[\text{VSL}_{c_i} = \text{VLY}_c \times T_{c_i}\] daedalus, country- age-specifc VSL values can accessed package data object daedalus::life_value. values also automatically accessed included <daedalus_country> object created, name vsl.
code: # load library for examples library(daedalus)  # create a <daedalus_country> x <- daedalus_country("China")  # access VSL values using either a helper function or # the subsetting operator get_data(x, "vsl") #> [1] 1322296.0 1166990.6  674010.6  177462.6  x$vsl #> [1] 1322296.0 1166990.6  674010.6  177462.6

title: General model description
text: daedalus package implementation deterministic epidemiological economic model emergence spread respiratory pathogen pandemics countries. Specifically, daedalus tracks Health impact terms infections, hospitalisations, deaths years life lost (YLL), Economic impact terms GDP losses : Economic sector closures workforce depletion due infection, hospitalisation death Present life-time economic losses missed education Human life losses using value statistical life approach Presently, equipped daedalus parameters simulate seven potential pathogens (influenza 2009, influenza 1957, influenza 1918, SARS-CoV-1, SARS-CoV-2 pre-Alpha variant, SARS-CoV-2 Delta SARS-CoV-2 Omicron BA.1, see table pathogen parameters) across 67 countries. addition, daedalus allows user flexibility incorporate additional respiratory pathogen /country parameters data, considered appropriate use case. following sections present technical description epidemiological economic components daedalus. examples implementation research case studies, see original description daedalus application UK COVID-19 pandemic Haw et al. (2022) Study societal value SARS-CoV-2 booster vaccination Indonesia Johnson et al. (2023) Study promoting healthy populations pandemic preparedness strategy Mexico Johnson et al. (2024)

title: General model description
text: daedalus simulates country’s population split seven possible disease state compartments. Model compartments stratified age-sector sector \(\) vaccination \(j\) classes. susceptible individual \(S\) can become exposed virus enter latent state \(E\), can develop either symptomatic \(I_s\) asymptomatic \(I_a\) infection. Whereas asymptomatic infected individuals assumed always recover, symptomatic ones can either recover \(R\) develop severe condition requiring hospitalisation lead either recovery \(H_r\) death \(H_d\). assume different lengths hospital stay compartments, individuals transition recovered \(R\) death \(D\) compartments.

title: General model description
text: \[ \begin{aligned}     & \frac{dS_{,j}}{dt} = \zeta_{eff_{j=0}}(t) S_{,j=0}(t) - \Lambda_{,j} (t) S_{,j}(t)  + \rho R_{,j}(t) - \zeta_{j=1} S_{,j=1}(t)\\     & \frac{dE_{,j}}{dt} = \Lambda_{,j} (t) S_{,j}(t) - \sigma E_{,j}(t) \\     & \frac{dIa_{,j}}{dt} = (1 - p_\text{symp}) \sigma E_{,j}(t) - \gamma_{I_a} I_{a_{,j}}(t) \\     & \frac{dIs_{,j}}{dt} = p_\text{symp} \sigma E_{,j}(t) - \gamma_{I_s} I_{s_{,j}}(t) - \eta^I_{s_{,j}}(t) \\     & \frac{dHr_{,j}}{dt} = \eta^(1 - \text{HFR}_{}) I_{s_{,j}}(t) - \gamma_{H_r} H_{r_{,j}}(t) \\     & \frac{dHd_{,j}}{dt} = \eta^\text{HFR}_{} I_{s_{,j}}(t) - \gamma_{H_d} H_{d_{,j}}(t) \\     & \frac{dR_{,j}}{dt} = \zeta_{eff_{j=0}}(t) R_{,j=0}(t) + \gamma_{I_s} I_{s_{,j}}(t) + \gamma_{Ia} Ia_{,j}(t) + \gamma_{Hr} Hr_{,j}(t) - \rho R_{,j}(t) - \zeta_{j=1} R_{,j=1}(t)\\     & \frac{dD_{,j}}{dt} = \gamma_{Hd} Hd_{,j}(t)\\ \end{aligned} \] noted whilst model parameters vary time (e.g., \(\zeta_{eff_{j=0}}(t)\) effective vaccination rate scaled available susceptible population) others assumed fixed (e.g., \(\sigma\) constant rate \(E \rightarrow \) progression), indicated \((t)\). One parameter varies endogenously age-specific mortality rate \(\omega^\); mortality rates groups increased 160% total number individuals ‘hospitalised’ compartment exceeds country-specific surge hospital capacity available responding outbreak. Note , default, daedalus ships collection pre-defined parameter sets represent historical respiratory pandemic pathogens (see table pathogen parameters), contained daedalus.data. can saved object class daedalus_infection modified user passed model function [daedalus::daedalus()].

title: General model description
text: 49 age-sector classes \(\) daedalus: four age \(\1:4\) groups \(([0, 5), [5, 20), [20-65), 65+)\) , given population \(=3\) (20–64 years old) represents unemployed adults ofr working age, 45 economic groups \(\5:49\) (see section economic model ).

title: General model description
text: default, daedalus disaggregates population vaccination classes \(j \1:2\) unvaccinated vaccinated. assume population susceptible recovered compartments can vaccinated, given transition rate \(\zeta_{\text{eff}_{j=0}}(t)\), determined user (see table vaccination scenario parameters). Vaccinated individuals can lose immunity transition back unvaccinated class, given rate \(\rho\).

title: General model description
text: daedalus can simulate nine different pathogens (influenza 2009, influenza 1957, influenza 1918, SARS-CoV-1, SARS-CoV-2 pre-Alpha variant, SARS-CoV-2 Delta SARS-CoV-2 Omicron BA.1) pathogen-specific transition (see table pathogen parameters). Table: Definition model transition parameters.

title: General model description
text: given pathogen, assume seed \(10^{-7}\) infections, assumed symptomatic. force infection \(\lambda_{,j} (t)\) accounts infection contributions symptomatically \(I_{s_{ij}}(t)\) asymptomatically \(I_{a_{ij}}(t)\) infected individuals community workplaces. let \(\delta I_{\text{comm}}^(t)\) \(\delta I_{\text{work}}^(t)\) denote number infected individuals community workplace, respectively, weighted infectivity given \[ \begin{aligned}     & \delta I_{\text{comm}_{ij}}(t) = v_{eff_{j=1}} (I_{a_{\1:4,j}}(t) \epsilon + I_{s_{\1:4,j}}(t))\\     & \delta I_{\text{work}_{ij}}(t) = v_{eff_{j=1}} (I_{a_{\5:49,j}}(t) \epsilon + I_{s_{\5:49,j}}(t)) \end{aligned} \] \(\epsilon\) relative infectiousness asymptomatically infected individual relative symptomatic one, \(v_{\text{eff}_{j=1}}\) reduced susceptibility vaccinated individual relative unvaccinated one age. force infection community \(\lambda_{\text{comm}_{,j}} (t)\) susceptible individual thus modelled \[ \lambda_{\text{comm}_{,j}} (t) = \beta (t) \cdot \sum_{'} m_{,'} \sum_{j'} \delta I_{{\text{comm}}_{',j'}} (t) \] \(\beta(t)\) represents time-varying contact rate scaling factor, determined social distancing interventions simulated, \(m_{,'}\) (symmetric) person--person contact rate age group \(\) \('\). force infection within workplace \(\lambda_{work_{,j}} (t)\) modelled \[ \lambda_{\text{work}_{,j}} (t) = \beta (t) \cdot \Phi_i(t) \cdot \sum_{'=0}^{'=N} C_{,'} \sum_{j'} \delta I_{\text{work}_{',j'}} (t) \] \(C_{,'}\) contact matrix specific workplace, \(\Phi_i(t)\) scaling factor determined economic closure interventions simulated. Lastly, force infection infected individuals community susceptible workers \(\lambda_{\text{comm}\rightarrow\text{workers}_{,j}} (t)\) (.e., infected individuals community attending shops) given \[ \lambda_{\text{comm}\rightarrow\text{workers}_{,j}} (t) =     \beta (t) \cdot \Phi_i(t) \cdot \sum_{'=0}^{'=N} {C \rightarrow W}_{,'} \sum_{j'} \delta I_{{\text{comm}}_{',j'}} (t) \] \(C \rightarrow W_{,'}\) contact matrix specific consumers attending workplaces. total force infection acting susceptible individuals assumed addition . conciseness, can taken \[     \Lambda_{ij} (t) = \lambda_{\text{comm}_{ij}} (t) + \lambda_{\text{work}_{ij}} (t) + \lambda_{\text{comm}\rightarrow\text{workers}_{,j}} (t) \] however, noted force infection within workplace \(\lambda_{work_{ij}} (t)\) column vector length 45, given number economic sector classes model, whilst \(\lambda_{\text{comm}_{ij}} (t)\) \(\lambda_{\text{comm}\rightarrow\text{workers}_{,j}} (t)\) length 49, encompassing age-sector classes.

title: General model description
text: daedalus assigns monetary values three key types model outcomes interpret losses: years life lost due epidemic-related deaths, economic activity lost due worker illness epidemic mitigation measures, years education lost due worker illnesses epidemic mitigation measures. life-years lost education-days lost valuations models explained detail vignettes (see links ), focus valuation economic losses. Value life-years lost: Calculated using value statistical life approach based country-specific gross national income (broadest possible data source); see vignette value life-years lost calculated. Value education-days lost: Calculated using approach based present value future earnings; see vignette value educational time lost calculated.

title: General model description
text: calculate cost economic closures 45 \(k\) sectors terms lost gross value added (GVA). daedalus runs continuous time, outputs calculated daily time steps. daily GDP generated country absence closures composed maximum daily GVA \(y_k(t)\) sector \(k\). 1:1 mapping 45 economic sectors age-sector population strata \(\5:49\). conciseness, section index economic sectors age-sector classes \(k\). Formally, maximum possible GDP generated \(Y_0(t)\) economic sectors \(m_S\) absence mandated closures (.e., result non-pharmaceutical interventions restrict economic workplace capacity) time \(t\) defined \[ Y_0(t)=\sum_{k=1}^{m_S}y_k(t), \] economic sectors contribute daily GVA \(y_k(t)\). economic sector , however, affected closures given day, estimate GVA losses \[ y_k(t) = y_k(0) \cdot (1 - \kappa_k(t)) \] \(y_k(0)\) respective sector’s daily GVA absence closure \(\kappa_k(t)\) relative openness (.e., 0 1, 0 completely open 1 completely closed). thus assume sectors contribute $0 USD GVA day \(t\) completely closed. addition GVA losses closures, economic sectors can lose productivity whilst open given depletion workforce (.e., due self-isolation, sickness, hospitalisation death). \(x_{k}(t)\) proportion workforce contributing economic production sector \(k\) total workforce \(N_k\) day \(t\). workforce sector depleted, assume smaller fraction \(\hat{x}_{j}(t)\) available contribute production given \[ \hat{x}_{k}(t) = x_{k}(t) \left(1 - \sum_{j=0}^{1} \left( \frac{I_a^{j,k}(t) + I_s^{j,k}(t) + H^{j,k}(t) + D^{j,k}(t)}{N_k} \right) \right). \] total GDP generated time \(t\) \[ Y(t) = \sum_{k=1}^{m_S} y_k(t) \hat{x}_{k}(t), \] GDP loss compared maximum \[ \int_{t=0}^t \left( Y_0(t) - Y(t) \right)dt. \]

title: Modelling time-limited economic closures
text: time-limited economic closure NPI created passing values start_time end_time arguments daedalus_npi(). instance, specify school closures U.K. active days 30 90 pandemic use code.
code: npi <- daedalus_npi(   "school_closures", "GBR", "sars_cov_1",   start_time = 30, end_time = 90 )  # see NPI information npi #> <daedalus_npi/daedalus_response> #> NPI strategy: school_closures #> • Start time (days): 30 #> • End time (days): 90 #> • Openness (mean prop.): 0.93 #> • Maximum duration (days): 365  # run a scenario with the npi daedalus(   "GBR", "sars_cov_1", npi,   time_end = 100 ) #> <daedalus_output> #> • Country: United Kingdom #> • Epidemic: sars_cov_1 #> • NPI response: school_closures #> • Vaccination: no vaccination #> • Behaviour: no behaviour

title: Modelling time-limited economic closures
text: Creating time-limited NPI single active duration using daedalus_npi() requires: Passing NA name rather one pre-canned NPI strategies found [daedalus.data::closure_strategy_data], Passing vector length number economic sectors (currently 45) openness argument. country infection still required . rules requirements pre-canned response; pre-canned element openness coefficients. Passing bespoke NPI [daedalus()] leads resulting <daedalus_output> object identifying response_strategy "custom". See next section specify time-limited NPIs active multiple intervals.
code: openness <- rep(0.3, 45)  npi <- daedalus_npi(   NA, "GBR", "sars_cov_1",   openness,   30, 90 )  # see NPI information npi #> <daedalus_npi/daedalus_response> #> NPI strategy: custom #> • Start time (days): 30 #> • End time (days): 90 #> • Openness (mean prop.): 0.3 #> • Maximum duration (days): 365  # run a scenario with the npi daedalus(   "GBR", "sars_cov_1", npi,   time_end = 100 ) #> <daedalus_output> #> • Country: United Kingdom #> • Epidemic: sars_cov_1 #> • NPI response: custom #> • Vaccination: no vaccination #> • Behaviour: no behaviour

title: Modelling time-limited economic closures
text: time-limited response can set trigger end multiple time points. use real-time pandemic response use-cases users seeking model policy-makers’ options decisions imposing lifting restrictions. daedalus offers [daedalus_timed_npi()] function specify time-limited NPIs responsive model state, allow multiple closure periods. [daedalus_timed_npi()] also allows specifying different openness coefficient vector (.e., stringency economic closures) closure period, allows responses ramped — expected use-case real-time modelling. Repeated time-limited NPIs created passing vectors start_time end_time daedalus_timed_npi(). \(-th\) element vector gives start end time closure period. Note : [daedalus_timed_npi()] creates <daedalus_npi> object, just different event triggers; objects trigger end model state; objects specify maximum closure duration, require closure periods time-limited; closure periods must non-overlapping, one closure regime can active time; Sequential time-limited responses created tweaking pre-canned responses, openness coefficients may used accessing manually [daedalus.data::closure_strategy_data]. example show ramping responses switching school closures elimination strategy back .
code: school_closures <- daedalus.data::closure_strategy_data[["school_closures"]] elimination <- daedalus.data::closure_strategy_data[["elimination"]]  # start at day 30, 60, 90, 30 days each npi <- daedalus_timed_npi(   start_time = c(30, 60, 90),   end_time = c(59, 89, 120),   openness = list(     school_closures, elimination, school_closures   ),   "GBR" )  # see NPI information npi #> <daedalus_npi/daedalus_response> #> NPI strategy: custom_timed #> • Start time (days): 30, 60, and 90 #> • End time (days): 59, 89, and 120 #> • Openness (mean prop.): 0.93, 0.713, and 0.93 #> • Maximum duration (days): NA  # run a scenario with the npi output <- daedalus(   "GBR", "sars_cov_1", npi,   time_end = 150 )  # examine event times output$event_data #> NULL

title: Model Health, Social, and Economic Costs of a Pandemic
text: found following issues released versions: v0.1.0: Consumer-worker contacts correctly handled, leading higher faster epidemic peaks. v0.2.0: Consumer-worker contacts included model, leading lower later epidemic peaks. ‘recovered’ compartment include recoveries hospitalisation. Please use helper function get_epidemic_summary() get epidemic sizes.

title: Model Health, Social, and Economic Costs of a Pandemic

code: library(daedalus)  # run model for Canada output <- daedalus("Canada", "influenza_1918")  # view the output output #> <daedalus_output> #> • Country: Canada #> • Epidemic: influenza_1918 #> • NPI response: none #> • Vaccination: no vaccination #> • Behaviour: no behaviour  # get pandemic costs as a total in million dollars get_costs(output, "total") #> [1] 1469908  # disaggregate total for economic, education, and health costs get_costs(output, "domain") #>     economic    education   life_value   life_years  #>    29756.419     1897.382  1438253.766 31232437.916

title: Model Health, Social, and Economic Costs of a Pandemic
text: Selecting historical epidemic parameters: Users can select infection parameters among seven epidemics caused directly-transmitted viral respiratory pathogens, stored stand-alone helper package daedalus.data. can called daedalus.data::infection_data, epidemic identifiers stored daedalus.data::epidemic_names. Custom country infection parameters: Users can override default country contact data epidemic-specific infection arguments passing custom classes daedalus(); see package website details. Modelling pandemic mitigation measures: Users can also model implementation pandemic response measures: see documentation main model function daedalus(), vignette modelling interventions package website. Modelling parameter uncertainty: daedalus provides daedalus_multi_infection() function easily model outcomes multiple sets epidemic parameters, can used model outcomes parameter uncertainty; see vignette modelling parameter uncertainty .

title: Model Health, Social, and Economic Costs of a Pandemic
text: daedalus R implementation epidemic projections model based Haw et al. (2022) project economics pandemic preparedness. daedalus.data stand-alone helper R package handle input data daedalus model. purpose allow users flexibly manipulate change epidemiological economic data, without needing modify model . daedalus.compare R package sits downstream daedalus also wraps daedalus functions help users conveniently run multiple epidemic scenarios. daedalus.api R package connects daedalus DAEDALUS Explore dashboard.

title: Represent behaviour-change mechanisms in DAEDALUS — class_behaviour
code: daedalus_old_behaviour(rate = 0.001, lower_limit = 0.2)  daedalus_new_behaviour(   hospital_capacity,   behav_effectiveness = 0.5,   baseline_optimism = 0.5,   responsiveness = 1.5,   k0 = 4.59,   k1 = -9.19 )  is_daedalus_behaviour(x)  # S3 method for class 'daedalus_behaviour' print(x, ...)

title: Represent behaviour-change mechanisms in DAEDALUS — class_behaviour
text: rate marginal rate decrease scaling factor additional daily death 'old' behavioural model. lower_limit lower limit scaling factor 'old' behavioural model; prevents scaling factor reaching zero. hospital_capacity emergency hospital capacity country, may also <daedalus_country> object hospital capacity extracted. See \(\bar H\) Details. behav_effectiveness single double value effectiveness adopting behavioural measures risk infection. Expected range \([0, 1]\), 0 represents effectiveness, 1 represents full effectiveness. See \(\delta\) Details. Defaults 0.5. baseline_optimism single double value baseline optimism pandemic outcomes. Expected range \([0, 1]\). See \(\bar B\) Details. Defaults 0.5. responsiveness single double value population responsiveness epidemic signal. Must lower value 0, upper bound open. See \(k_2\) Details. Defaults 1.5. k0 single, optional double value scaling parameter sigmoidal relationship \(p_t\) behav_effectiveness. See \(k_0\) Details. Defaults 4.59. k1 single, optional double value another scaling parameter sigmoidal relationship \(p_t\) behav_effectiveness. See \(k_1\) Details. Defaults -9.19. Expected negative number. x <daedalus_behaviour> object. ... arguments passed format().

title: Represent behaviour-change mechanisms in DAEDALUS — class_behaviour
text: object class <daedalus_behaviour> inherits <daedalus_response>. primarily list holding behavioural parameters.

title: Represent behaviour-change mechanisms in DAEDALUS — class_behaviour
text: Daedalus currently supports two behavioural models (option neither model active). models simulate population-level changes towards adopting behaviours help reduce risk infection, might expected major disease outbreak. models, transmission rate infection \(\beta\) reduced transmissions scaling factor; models differ scaling factor calculated. Note major issue including model run (value "") leads substantially lower response costs, generally better health outcomes (lives lost), without accounting attendant economic social costs. , please treat behavioural models experimental.

title: Represent behaviour-change mechanisms in DAEDALUS — class_behaviour
text: model existed prior daedalus v0.2.25 referred "old" behavioural model. scaling factor \(\beta\) model $$ (1 - \text{rate})^{\Delta D} \times (1 - L) + L $$ \(\text{rate}\) marginal rate reduction additional death per day (\(\Delta D\)), \(L\) lower limit scaling factor prevent FOI going zero.

title: Represent behaviour-change mechanisms in DAEDALUS — class_behaviour
text: model referred "new" behavioural model, scaling factor \(\beta\) given $$ \mathcal{B}(p_t, \delta) = p_t(1 - \delta)[p_t(1 - \delta) + (1 - p_t)] + (1 - p_t)[p_t(1 - \delta) + (1 - p_t)] $$ \(p_t\) proportion population taking protective behaviour \(\delta\) effectiveness behaviour, range \([0, 1]\). either zero, \(\beta\) scaled . \(p_t\) computed model run, given $$ p_t = \frac{1}{1 + \text{exp}\left\{-\left(k_0 + k_1 \bar B + k_2 \frac{H_t}{\bar H}\right)\right\}} $$ \(k_0 = 4.59, k_1 = -9.19, k_2\) scaling parameters. \(k_0, k_1\) constant values changed user, chosen produce sigmoidal relationship \(\bar B\) \(p_t\). \(k_2\) constant user-supplied parameter interpreted population responsiveness signal epidemic severity \(H_t / \bar H\), relative burden hospital capacity (\(H_t\): hospital demand time \(t\), \(\bar H\): emergency hospital capacity). \(\bar B\) constant user-supplied parameter captures baseline population optimism outbreak.

title: Represent infection parameters for DAEDALUS — class_infection
text: Epidemics data available given (pathogen parentheses). string indicates name must passed name argument. "sars_cov_1": SARS 2004 (SARS-CoV-1), "influenza_2009": influenza 2009 (influenza H1N1), "influenza_1957": influenza 1957 (influenza H2N2), "influenza_1918": influenza 1918 (influenza H1N1), "sars_cov_2_pre_alpha": Covid-19 wild type (SARS-Cov-2 wild type), "sars_cov_2_omicron": Covid-19 Omicron (SARS-CoV-2 omicron), "sars_cov_2_pre_delta": (SARS-CoV-2 delta).

title: Represent infection parameters for DAEDALUS — class_infection
text: infections following parameters, take default values stored package daedalus.data::infection_data. Users can pass custom values parameters arguments via .... r0: single numeric value basic reproduction value infection \(R_0\). sigma: single numeric value > 0.0 rate transition exposed compartment one two infectious compartments. p_sigma: single numeric value range \([0.0, 1.0]\) proportion infectious individuals also symptomatic. Asymptomatic individuals can different contribution force infection symptomatic individuals. epsilon: single numeric value relative contribution asymptomatic infectious individuals force infection (compared symptomatic individuals). gamma_Is: single numeric value recovery rate infectious individuals hospitalised. gamma_Ia: single numeric value recovery rate asymptomatic infection. ifr: numeric vector length N_AGE_GROUPS (4) age-specific infection fatality risk. eta: numeric vector length N_AGE_GROUPS (4) age-specific hospitalisation rate individuals infectious symptomatic. hfr: numeric vector length N_AGE_GROUPS (4) age-specific probability death conditional hospitalisation. gamma_H_recovery: single numeric value recovery rate hospitalised individuals. gamma_H_death: single numeric value death rate hospitalised individuals. rho: single numeric value rate infection-derived immunity wanes, returning individuals 'recovered' compartment 'susceptible' compartment.

title: Represent infection parameters for DAEDALUS — class_infection
code: # make a <daedalus_infection> object with default parameter values daedalus_infection("sars_cov_1") #> <daedalus_infection> #> • Epidemic name: sars_cov_1 #> • R0: 1.75 #> • sigma: 0.217 #> • p_sigma: 0.867 #> • epsilon: 0.58 #> • rho: 0.003 #> • eta: 0.018, 0.082, 0.018, and 0.246 #> • hfr: 0.255, 0.255, 0.255, and 0.255 #> • gamma_Ia: 0.476 #> • gamma_Is: 0.25 #> • gamma_H_recovery: 0.044 #> • gamma_H_death: 0.05  # modify infection parameters R0 and immunity waning rate daedalus_infection("influenza_1918", r0 = 2.5, rho = 0.01) #> <daedalus_infection> #> • Epidemic name: influenza_1918 #> • R0: 2.5 #> • sigma: 0.909 #> • p_sigma: 0.669 #> • epsilon: 0.58 #> • rho: 0.01 #> • eta: 0.073, 0.064, 0.02, and 0.152 #> • hfr: 0.125, 0.125, 0.125, and 0.125 #> • gamma_Ia: 0.4 #> • gamma_Is: 0.4 #> • gamma_H_recovery: 0.2 #> • gamma_H_death: 0.2

title: Represent non-pharmaceutical intervention strategies for DAEDALUS — class_npi
text: name NPI strategy name among daedalus.data::closure_strategy_names, NA. Passing pre-defined strategy name automatically pulls openness parameters associated response strategy; stored packaged data daedalus.data::closure_strategy_data. Pass NA define custom response strategy passing vector openness. country country territory object class <daedalus_country>, country territory name included package; see daedalus.data::country_names, country ISO2 ISO3 code; see daedalus.data::country_codes_iso2c daedalus.data::country_codes_iso3c. Country-specific data community workplace contacts, demography, distribution workforce economic sectors automatically accessed package data relevant country name passed string. override package defaults country characteristics, pass <daedalus_country> object instead. See daedalus_country() . infection infection parameter object class <daedalus_infection>, epidemic name data provided package; see daedalus.data::epidemic_names historical epidemics epidemic waves parameters available. Passing name string automatically accesses default parameters infection. Create pass <daedalus_infection> tweak infection parameters using daedalus_infection(). openness daedalus_npi(), optional numeric vector giving openness economic sector model NPI effect. daedalus_timed_npi(), list numeric vectors giving openness coefficients interval specified corresponding elements start_time end_time. Expected length N_ECON_SECTORS (currently 45), values range \([0, 1]\), start_time daedalus_npi(), single number giving number days start model NPI response begins. Defaults 30. daedalus_timed_npi(): may vector NPI start times, default values. end_time daedalus_npi(), single number giving number days start model NPI response ends. Defaults NULL, indicating response ends (condition met), maximum duration. daedalus_timed_npi(): may vector NPI end times, default values. Timed NPIs default duration. max_duration maximum number days NPI response active whether started passing start_time state threshold crossed. Defaults 365 days. NPIs created using daedalus_timed_npi() default maximum duration encoded pairs start end times. x object tested printed <daedalus_npi>. ... daedalus_npi(), parameters passed new_daedalus_response(). print method, parameters passed print().

May one "daedalus_npi", "daedalus_vaccination", "daedalus_behaviour", "daedalus_mortality". default argument, users forced specify class building constructor. parameters Sub-class parameters passed sub-class constructors. Defaults empty list aid development. identifier optional string giving name pre-defined response strategy. Sub-class constructors helper functions provide names handle cases strategy custom one. id_flag Index state-flag changed response . Typically auto-calculated sub-class constructor helper functions; see e.g. daedalus_vaccination(). time_on Intended numeric vector start times. time_off Intended numeric vector end times. max_duration Intended number maximum duration. id_state_on Intended numeric vector compartment indices checked roots found launch event. check always performed sum state indices. value_state_on Intended numeric vector roots found change switch-like state-flag ''. check always performed sum state indices. id_state_off Intended numeric vector compartment indices checked roots found end event. value_state_off Intended numeric vector roots found change switch-like state-flag ''. root_state_on single integer, either 1 -1, whether state-dependent launch increasing decreasing root, respectively. Defaults 1 increasing root common use case. root_state_off single integer, either 1 -1, whether state-dependent end increasing decreasing root, respectively. Defaults -1 decreasing root common use case. id_time_log Intended single number state index start-time response stored. See also initial_flags(). attribute intended solely enable time-limitation state-triggers. x functions taking x, must object class <daedalus_response>, object validated class.

title: DAEDALUS model for health, social and economic costs of a pandemic — daedalus
text: country country territory object class <daedalus_country>, country territory name included package; see daedalus.data::country_names, country ISO2 ISO3 code; see daedalus.data::country_codes_iso2c daedalus.data::country_codes_iso3c. Country-specific data community workplace contacts, demography, distribution workforce economic sectors automatically accessed package data relevant country name passed string. override package defaults country characteristics, pass <daedalus_country> object instead. See daedalus_country() . infection infection parameter object class <daedalus_infection>, epidemic name data provided package; see daedalus.data::epidemic_names historical epidemics epidemic waves parameters available. Passing name string automatically accesses default parameters infection. Create pass <daedalus_infection> tweak infection parameters using daedalus_infection(). response_strategy string name response strategy followed, numeric length 45 (number economic sectors), <daedalus_npi> object. Defaults "none". response strategy active, economic contacts scaled using package data object daedalus.data::closure_strategy_data. vaccine_investment Either single string <daedalus_vaccination> object specifying vaccination parameters associated advance vaccine-investment scenario. Defaults NULL absolutely vaccination model. vaccination investment "none" indicates prior investment, model include vaccination beginning 1 year, low rate across age groups. accepted values "low", "medium" "high". See daedalus_vaccination() information. behaviour optional object class <daedalus_behaviour> determines population-level perception epidemic signals affects infection transmission. May NULL behavioural modification infection transmission. See <daedalus_behaviour> class documentation details available behavioural mechanisms response_time single numeric value time days selected response activated. ignored response already activated hospitalisation threshold reached. Defaults 30 days. Responses default maximum duration 365 days. can changed passing <daedalus_npi> object response_strategy. initial_state_manual optional named list names p_infectious, p_asymptomatic, p_immune. p_infectious p_asymptomatic give proportion infectious symptomatic individuals age group economic sector. Defaults 1e-6 0.0 respectively. p_immune may single number range 0.0 <= p_immune <= 1.0 4-element vector range (number age groups model), proportion individuals population age group pre-existing immunity infection (reduced susceptibility). See Details . time_end integer-like value number timesteps return data. treated number days data returned day. Defaults 300 days. ... Optional arguments passed dust2::dust_ode_control().

title: DAEDALUS model for health, social and economic costs of a pandemic — daedalus
text: <daedalus_output> object infection string single <daedalus_infection> object.

title: DAEDALUS model for health, social and economic costs of a pandemic — daedalus
text: Users can pass following initial state parameters initial_state_manual: p_infectious: single numeric value range \([0.0, 1.0]\) giving proportion individuals age group economic sector initialised infectious. Defaults 1e-6, one every one million infectious. p_asymptomatic: single numeric value range \([0.0, 1.0]\) proportion initially infectious individuals considered asymptomatic. Defaults 0.0. p_immune: Either single number vector 4 elements (number age groups) range \([0.0, 1.0]\) proportion population (age group) considered pre-existing immunity. stop-gap implementation assumes one two cases: (1) vaccination intended model vaccine_investment NULL, susceptibility individuals pre-existing immunity 50%; (2) vaccination strategy specified, pre-existing immunity assumed prior rollout, susceptibility determined chosen vaccination strategy (1 - efficacy).

title: DAEDALUS model for health, social and economic costs of a pandemic — daedalus
code: # country and infection specified by strings using default characteristics output <- daedalus(   "Canada", "influenza_1918" )  # print output output #> <daedalus_output> #> • Country: Canada #> • Epidemic: influenza_1918 #> • NPI response: none #> • Vaccination: no vaccination #> • Behaviour: no behaviour  # country passed as <daedalus_country> with some characteristics modified country_x <- daedalus_country(   "Canada",   parameters = list(contact_matrix = matrix(5, 4, 4)) # uniform contacts ) output <- daedalus(country_x, "influenza_1918")  # with some infection parameters over-ridden by the user output <- daedalus(   "United Kingdom",   daedalus_infection("influenza_1918", r0 = 1.3) )  # with default initial conditions over-ridden by the user output <- daedalus(   "United Kingdom", "influenza_1918",   initial_state_manual = list(p_infectious = 1e-3) )  # including behavioural modification output <- daedalus(   "Canada", "influenza_1918",   behaviour = daedalus_old_behaviour(),   time_end = 100 )

text: COMPARTMENTS returns character vector epidemiological compartment names. idx_COMPARTMENTS returns list compartment index. constants return integer values.

title: Epidemiological compartments and indices — epi_constants
text: DAEDALUS 8 epidemiological compartments: susceptible, exposed, infectious symptomatic ("infect_symp"), infectious asymptomatic ("infect_asymp") , hospitalised leading recovery ("hospitalised_recov"), hospitalised leading death ("hospitalised_death"), recovered, dead. 2 additional compartments track number new infections new hospitalisations.

what: Calculate daily incidences and summarise epidemic measures — epi_output_helpers
title: Calculate daily incidences and summarise epidemic measures — epi_output_helpers
text: Functions quickly summarise timeseries data daedalus() provide daily values infections, hospitalisations, deaths, vaccinations, allowing grouping different strata.

title: Calculate daily incidences and summarise epidemic measures — epi_output_helpers
code: get_incidence(   data,   measures = c("infections", "hospitalisations", "deaths"),   groups = NULL )  get_epidemic_summary(   data,   measures = c("infections", "hospitalisations", "deaths"),   groups = NULL )  get_new_vaccinations(data, groups = NULL)

title: Calculate daily incidences and summarise epidemic measures — epi_output_helpers
text: data Either <data.frame> call get_data() <daedalus_output> object, object directly. measures character vector one following, passed get_incidence() get_epidemic_summary(): "infections", "hospitalisations" "deaths" measure return. Defaults returning three long format. get_daily_vaccinations() accept measures argument provides number daily vaccinations. groups optional character vector grouping variables correspond model strata. Defaults NULL gives incidence across whole population. Allowed groups correspond modelled strata: "age_group", "vaccine_group", "econ_sector". get_daily_vaccinations() accepts "age_group" "econ_sector".

title: Calculate daily incidences and summarise epidemic measures — epi_output_helpers
text: <data.frame> long format, one entry per model timestep, measure, group chosen. get_incidence() returns data frame number daily new infections, new hospitalisations, /new deaths groups specified groups. get_epidemic_summary() returns data frame total number value specified measure groups specified groups. get_daily_vaccinations() returns data frame columns number new daily vaccination combination groups provided. Columns groups added groups specified.

title: Calculate daily incidences and summarise epidemic measures — epi_output_helpers
code: data <- daedalus("Canada", "sars_cov_1")  # new infections new_infections <- get_incidence(data, "infections")  # epidemic summary get_epidemic_summary(   data,   groups = "age_group" ) #>    age_group       value                measure #> 1        0-4    52652.96           total_deaths #> 2       5-19   489463.68           total_deaths #> 3      20-64   346745.61           total_deaths #> 4        65+   680990.67           total_deaths #> 5        0-4  2396014.16          epidemic_size #> 6       5-19  5855432.86          epidemic_size #> 7      20-64 15386117.07          epidemic_size #> 8        65+  4012735.55          epidemic_size #> 9        0-4   135385.18 total_hospitalisations #> 10      5-19  1240476.52 total_hospitalisations #> 11     20-64   875159.70 total_hospitalisations #> 12       65+  1712445.08 total_hospitalisations  # get daily vaccinations daily_vaccinations <- get_new_vaccinations(data)

Select "none", default, raw costs along overall domain-specific totals; "total" overall cost, "domain" total costs per domain; domains 'economic', 'education', 'life years'. productivity_loss_infection single number range \([0, 1]\) giving loss productivity associated symptomatic infection. what: Get pandemic fiscal costs from a model run — get_fiscal_costs
title: Get pandemic fiscal costs from a model run — get_fiscal_costs
text: helper function post-processes <daedalus_output> object calculate costs national government (fiscal costs) responding pandemic. Includes costs economic support, vaccinations given, NPIs administered implemented.

title: Get pandemic fiscal costs from a model run — get_fiscal_costs
code: get_fiscal_costs(   x,   support_level = 0.2,   price_vax = 1,   price_npi = 1,   uptake_npi = 1,   interest_rate = 4,   tax_rate = 35,   spending_rate = 45,   starting_debt = 0,   productivity_loss_infection = 1 )

title: Get pandemic fiscal costs from a model run — get_fiscal_costs
text: x <daedalus_output> object call daedalus(). support_level proportion pandemic-related economic losses government compensates, proportion. price_vax per-dose price vaccination. price_npi per-day per-person price implementing pandemic response. May include costs testing masks. uptake_npi extent NPIs taken population; essentially number modifies (reduces) total cost implementing NPI. interest_rate annual interest rate government borrowing pandemic response. tax_rate annual mean tax rate economic output; used calculate government revenue. spending_rate annual mean rate public spending percentage GDP. starting_debt value national starting debt. Currently assumed zero country-specific data collected. productivity_loss_infection single number range \([0, 1]\) giving loss productivity associated symptomatic infection. Currently defaults 1.0 compatibility earlier function versions.

title: Get pandemic fiscal costs from a model run — get_fiscal_costs
text: two-element list giving: list fiscal_costs elements giving fiscal costs \(\text{TCG}_t\) breakdown costs, well interest; list public_debt public debt \(b_t\), net baseline public spending, pandemic response costs, pandemic-impacted revenue.

title: Get pandemic fiscal costs from a model run — get_fiscal_costs
text: Default argument values intended representative. function intended called daedalus() parameters required compute fiscal costs may need bundled along model outputs. Note rates (interest rate, spending rate, tax rate) given annual percentages. interest rate converted daily value annual one use compounding.

title: Get pandemic fiscal costs from a model run — get_fiscal_costs
text: Spending calculated : $$G_t = \sigma(\text{GVA}^* - \text{GVA}_t) + Cv_t + Cp_t$$ \(Cv_t\) time-specific cost vaccination, calculated cost new vaccinations timestep: \(P_v \times \delta V_t\) . \(Cp_t\) time-specific cost implementing pandemic response, calculated \(\psi (\bar N - D_t) P_p\), \(\bar N - D_t\) remaining number individuals population, \(\psi\) proportion taking protection offered response.

what: Interest on spending and fiscal cost
title: Get pandemic fiscal costs from a model run — get_fiscal_costs
text: assume government borrows spend pandemic mitigation measures outlined total cost public $$\text{TCG}_t = G_t + (1 + R_t^T) \text{TCG}_{t - 1}$$ \(R_t^T\) daily rate interest paid borrowed amount. interest rate modelled constant time. Users pass annual rate interest percentage, converted daily rate using internal function annual_rate_daily() \((1 + R_t^T)^{1 / 365} - 1\).

title: Get pandemic fiscal costs from a model run — get_fiscal_costs
text: total public debt end pandemic \(b_t\) sum : total public spending pandemic \(\text{TCG}_t\), existing day--day public spending \(\bar G\) assumed fraction daily GDP \(\nu \text{GDP}\), existing debt owed due past daily spending (including pandemic mitigation), interest paid debt, less revenues collected taxation, \(\mu \text{GVA}_{t-1}\), \(\mu\) mean rate taxation. daily GVA pre-pandemic GVA scaled available labour supply pandemic, taking account labour restrictions due illness-related absences deaths, response-related restrictions. GDP calculated sum sector-specific daily GVA, existing debt currently assumed zero included equation. $$b_t = \bar G + \text{TCG}_{t-1} + (1 + R_{t-1}^T) b_{t-1} -   \mu \text{GVA}_{t-1} $$

title: DAEDALUS model constants — model_constants
text: DAEDALUS model requires following values fixed. Number age groups: 4 Number vaccination strata: 2 Age group bins: 0-4 years, 5-19 years, 20-65 years (working age), 65+ years Index working-age age groups: 3; see AGE_GROUPS Number economic sectors: 45 Index individuals working layer 3D state tensor: 1 Number economic strata: 46; note always one number economic sectors, additional stratum work includes individuals working age, proportion working age individuals. Array dimension age groups: 1 Array dimension epidemiological compartments: 2 Array dimension economic sectors: 3 Array dimension vaccination strata: 4 Indices numbers key groups. Number state variables flags, switches, indicators.

title: daedalus 0.3.0
text: minor version release use Jameel Institute Symposium Daedalus preview event. Updates information NPI closures returned get_data.daedalus_npi(x, "openness"). Updates epidemic size test avoid potentially spurious failures ‘school closures’ seems worse ‘none’. Updates vignettes fix formatting table section linking. Updates Readme make information easier find.

title: daedalus 0.2.38
text: development version splits H two compartments uses HFR probability death conditional hospitalisation (PR #109).

title: daedalus 0.2.38
text: Hospital compartments now named Hr Hd, hospitalised leading recovery death, respectively. C++ code, people enter Hd given change affect downstream packages daedalus.api daedalus.compare, effect daedalus.data. daedalus user experience remains unchanged.

title: daedalus 0.2.37
text: patch version: Implements new mechanism modify infection transmission rate \(\beta\) due population-level behaviour (via @kunph7); Adds header daedalus_behaviour.h new behavioural scaling functions, adds helper functions capture behavioural parameters R use ODE RHS using lambdas; Implements constructors <daedalus_behaviour> class inherits <daedalus_response>: currently simple parameter list, can extended full-fledged daedalus::events::response needed. Implements constructors ‘old’ ‘new’ behavioural mechanisms daedalus_old_behaviour() daedalus_new_behaviour() — create class object different parameters;

title: daedalus 0.2.37
text: Removes auto_social_distancing argument daedalus() daedalus_multi_infection() replaces behaviour argument.

title: daedalus 0.2.36
text: patch version allows NPIs end reaction epidemic signal (PR #122). Converts daedalus_ode class mixed-time ODE system uses update functionality access dy end NPIs based instantaneous value \(R_t\); Adds functionality calculate \(R_t\) ODE model; adds functionality easily get next-generation matrix R; Updates function get_beta() include workplace contacts age-specific contact matrix; Allows \(R_t\) time-series returned model runs; Updates event times inferred event_data longer returned part <daedalus_output>; manual NPI ending using update picked event; Updates costs functions tests renamed output elements; Updates number snapshot tests due reduction transmission rate \(\beta\) updates get_beta(); Updates daedalus::events make event generation logic daedalus::events::response clearer.

title: daedalus 0.2.35
text: patch version fixes closures scale within-sector worker-worker contact rates quadratic rather linear, increases impact applying response strategy model run (PR #126 @patcatgit).

title: daedalus 0.2.34
text: patch modifies costs fiscal costs calculation changing absences due illness calculated get_costs() get_fiscal_costs() (PR #115 reviewed @robj411). \(H\) \(D\) counted fully absent; \(I_a\) previously counted longer counted absent; \(I_s\) counted present work calculating new workplace infections, also complete productivity loss. level productivity loss can changed get_costs() get_fiscal_costs() using argument productivity_loss_infection. Snapshot tests updated reflect costs reduced due longer counting \(I_a\).

title: daedalus 0.2.34
text: get_fiscal_costs() updated: Labour availability match multiplicative implementation get_costs(); Interest rate, spending rate, tax rate corrected rates rather percentages, interest rate converted annual daily rate; GVA gap now accounts government support.

title: daedalus 0.2.33
text: patch version allows multiple, sequential, time-limited NPIs varying effects (PR #117). Added function daedalus_timed_npi() create time-limited NPIs responsive model state, accept multiple start end times (non-overlapping intervals), corresponding openness coefficients. Changes <daedalus_npi> accommodate timed NPIs. Changes C++ daedalus::events::response class log index timed events: allows indexing NPI coefficients, retains boolean flag responses. Function daedalus_npi() longer specifies default end time, allow multiple start end times (moved daedalus_timed_npi()). Updated vignette timed NPIs show multiple timed-NPI functionality different openness coefficients.

title: daedalus 0.2.32
text: patch version demotes auto_social_distancing full daedalus::events::response retaining mechanism behavioural effects (PR #113). mechanism options mostly handled R side (options "" "independent", setting initial flag values), "npi_linked" handled C++ side (setting reference flag index i_npi_flag). allows mechanism remain NPI-linked necessary without needing specify time- state-dependence rules separately. internal function daedalus::events::switch_by_flag converts flag values > 1.0 1.0 internally account changes NPI flag implicit index PR #117.

title: daedalus 0.2.31
text: patch version adds functionality allow multiple, sequential, time-limited NPIs (PR #111 reviewed @pabloperguz). <daedalus_response> sub-classes separate time_off max_duration members; time_off may vector max_duration single number defaulting 365 <daedalus_npi> . <daedalus_vaccination> default value allowing events continue indefinitely. Events returned daedalus() now differentiate time-limitation maximum-duration events; internal function get_daedalus_response_times() handles different names. C++ class daedalus::events::response now expects members time_on time_off vectors; handled <daedalus_npi> <daedalus_vaccination> via daedalus::inputs::read_response manually set events. C++ class daedalus::events::response member function make_time_test now checks start end time expected_value argument expected value flag. Function make_duration_test handles condition maximum duration reached. new vignette timed_response.Rmd shows use time-limitation functionality <daedalus_npi>. General tests events test-daedalus_events.R moved either NPI vaccination test files.

title: daedalus 0.2.0
text: minor version release {daedalus} adds real-time epidemic modelling functionality removing implementation vaccination vaccination-group infection pathways. intervening versions v0.1.0. NOTE: version following identified errors: Consumer--worker infections correctly handled leading later lower epidemic peaks expected. number recovered include recoveries hospitalisation. Changes Added new function daedalus_rtm() (real-time modelling) returns either <daedalus_output> object list . Rcpp backed using RcppEigen Boost Headers {BH} Boost odeint solvers; added Rcpp, RcppEigen, BH dependencies; Removes reactive intervention implementation lifting; instead single intervention economic sectors can passed implementation user-specified time-frame ; Allows NPI social contacts (basic scaling transmission rate \(\beta\)) economic sector NPI active (default 1.0 distancing); see arg social_distancing_mandate; Allows spontaneous social distancing mediated daily deaths turned (default); see arg auto_social_distancing; Allows passing 45-element numeric vector specifying sector-wise openness coefficients; Allows passing list <daedalus_infection> objects infection accommodate parameter uncertainty (case returns list <daedalus_output>); Hosptial capacity determines excess mortality activated; Initial state asumes 1 10 million infected. Added C++ code src/daedalus.cpp help ODE RHS, observer ODE system, looping parameter combinations, exposing C++ code R. Added functions help daedalus_rtm(): prepare_output_cpp() handle output Rcpp fn (returned list matrices); make_conmat_large() prepares 49 \(\times\) 49 contact matrix C++ ODE RHS; make_work_contacts() make_consumer_contacts() scale contacts workers economic sectors – \(N\) \(\beta SI \text{CM} / N\). Package classes: <daedalus_country> now returns life expectancy vector; Package data: Exporting economic sector names; Exporting country-wise life-expectancy data; Added C++-model compartment names constant. Downstream functions: get_costs() returns life-years lost; values lives lost vector renamed life_value_lost get_life_years_lost() calculates life-years lost total deaths life-expectancy. Package infrastructure: Updated .Rbuildignore, .gitignore, .lintr, _pkgdown.yml, WORDLIST C++ code; Updated Readmes reflect package title scope; Added basic tests daedalus_rtm().
